HeartView 1.0 documentation
previous | next | modules | index

API Reference¶

Pipeline¶

ECG¶

heartview.pipeline.ECG.baseline_muscle_filter(data, lowcut, highcut, fs, order=4)[source]¶

Filter out baseline wander and muscle noise.

Parameters:

  • data (array_like) – An array containing the noisy signal data.

  • lowcut (int, float) – The lower cut-off frequency.

  • highcut (int, float) – The higher cut-off frequency.

  • fs (int, float) – The sampling rate of the signal recording.

  • order (int) – The filter order, i.e., the number of samples required to produce the desired filtered output; by default, 4.’

Returns:

filtered – An array containing the filtered signal data.

Return type:

array_like

heartview.pipeline.ECG.compute_ibis(data, ts_col, peaks_ix)[source]¶

Compute interbeat intervals from peak locations in ECG data.

Parameters:

  • data (pd.DataFrame) – The data frame containing the ECG data and a timestamp column.

  • ts_col (str) – The name of the column containing timestamp values.

  • peaks_ix (array_like) – An array of indices corresponding to peak occurrences.

Returns:

ibi – A data frame containing timestamps and IBI values.

Return type:

pd.DataFrame

heartview.pipeline.ECG.detect_rpeaks(df, signal, fs)[source]¶

Detect locations of R peaks with Shannon energy & smooth envelope extraction.

Parameters:

  • df (pd.DataFrame) – The data frame containing the pre-processed ECG data.

  • signal (str) – The name of the column containing the filtered ECG data.

  • fs (int, float) – The sampling rate of the signal recording.

Returns:

id_maxes – Array containing the index locations of all detected peaks.

Return type:

np.array

heartview.pipeline.ECG.get_fs(edf)[source]¶

Get ECG sampling rate from an Actiwave Cardio device.

Parameters:

edf (str) – The path of the Actiwave Cardio EDF file.

Returns:

fs – The sampling rate of the Actiwave Cardio recording.

Return type:

int, float

heartview.pipeline.ECG.get_seconds(df, peaks_col, fs, seg_size)[source]¶

Get second-by-second HR, IBI, and peak counts from ECG data.

Parameters:

  • df (pd.DataFrame) – The data frame containing the ECG data and a timestamp column.

  • peaks_col (str) – The name of the column containing peak instances.

  • fs (int) – The sampling rate.

  • seg_size (int) – The window size of each segment.

Returns:

interval_data – A data frame containing IBI values.

Return type:

pd.DataFrame

heartview.pipeline.ECG.powerline_int_filter(data, fs, q, freq=60)[source]¶

Filter out powerline interference at a specified frequency.

Parameters:

  • data (array_like) – An array containing the noisy signal data.

  • fs (int, float) – The sampling rate of the signal recording.

  • q (float) – The quality factor, i.e., how narrow or wide the stopband is for a notch filter. A higher quality factor indicates a narrower bandpass.

  • freq (int, float) – The frequency to filter out (e.g., 50 or 60 Hz); by default, 60 Hz.

Returns:

filtered – An array containing the filtered signal data.

Return type:

array_like

heartview.pipeline.ECG.read_actiwave(edf)[source]¶

Read ECG and acceleration data from an Actiwave Cardio device.

Parameters:

edf (str) – The path of the Actiwave Cardio EDF file.

Returns:

  • ecg (pd.DataFrame) – The ECG data containing ‘Timestamp’ and ‘mV’ columns.

  • acc (pd.DataFrame) – The acceleration data containing ‘Timestamp’, ‘X’, ‘Y’, and ‘Z’ columns.

PPG¶

heartview.pipeline.PPG.get_e4_interval_data(df, seg_size)[source]¶

Get second-by-second HR values from Empatica E4 IBI data.

Parameters:

  • df (pandas.DataFrame) – The DataFrame output from get_e4_peaks.

  • seg_size (int) – The window size of each segment.

Returns:

interval_data – A DataFrame containing second-by-second HR and IBI values and peak counts.

Return type:

pandas.DataFrame

heartview.pipeline.PPG.get_e4_peaks(ibi, fs, start_time)[source]¶

Get HR values and peak locations from Empatica E4 IBI data.

Parameters:

  • ibi (pandas.DataFrame) – The DataFrame containing the pre-processed IBI data.

  • fs (int, float) – The sampling rate of the Empatica E4 recording.

  • start_time (int) – The Unix timestamp of the recording start time.

Returns:

df – A DataFrame containing peak occurrence and IBI and HR values at each timepoint.

Return type:

pandas.DataFrame

heartview.pipeline.PPG.get_fs(file)[source]¶

Get the sampling rate from an Empatica E4 file.

Parameters:

file (str) – The path of the Empatica E4 file.

Returns:

fs – The sampling rate of the Empatica E4 recording.

Return type:

int, float

heartview.pipeline.PPG.get_start_time(file)[source]¶

Get the Unix-formatted start time of an Empatica E4 recording.

Parameters:

file (str) – The path of the Empatica E4 file.

Returns:

start – The Unix timestamp of the recording start time.

Return type:

int

heartview.pipeline.PPG.preprocess_e4(e4_zip)[source]¶

Pre-process Empatica E4 data.

Parameters:

e4_zip (str) – The path of the Empatica E4 archive file ending in .zip.

Returns:

e4_data – A dictionary containing all pre-processed BVP, HR, IBI, and ACC data, as well as the sampling rate and start time of the recording.

Return type:

dict

ACC¶

heartview.pipeline.ACC.compute_magnitude(x, y, z)[source]¶

Compute the magnitude of a 3-axis accelerometer signal.

Parameters:

  • x (array_like) – An array containing the x-axis accelerometer data.

  • y (array_like) – An array containing the y-axis accelerometer data.

  • z (array_like) – An array containing the z-axis accelerometer data.

Returns:

magnitude – A series of acceleration magnitude values.

Return type:

pd.Series

Signal Quality Assessment (SQA)¶

heartview.pipeline.SQA.compute_metrics(df)[source]¶

Compute SQA metrics by segment from the peaks_by_seg output.

Parameters:

df (pandas.DataFrame) – The DataFrame containing the number of detected and the expected number of peaks per segment.

Returns:

metrics – A DataFrame with computed SQA metrics per segment.

Return type:

pandas.DataFrame

heartview.pipeline.SQA.display_summary_table(df)[source]¶

Display the SQA summary table.

Parameters:

df (pandas.DataFrame) – The DataFrame containing the SQA metrics per segment.

Returns:

table – Summary table for SQA metrics.

Return type:

dash_bootstrap_components.Table

heartview.pipeline.SQA.evaluate_peaks(df, seg_size)[source]¶

Get the number of detected and expected number of peaks per segment.

Parameters:

  • df (pandas.DataFrame) – The input data frame containing the second-by-second heart rates, interbeat intervals, and peak counts.

  • seg_size (int) – The segment size of each segment.

Returns:

peaks_by_seg – A DataFrame with the number of detected and the expected number of peaks per segment.

Return type:

pandas.DataFrame

heartview.pipeline.SQA.plot_expected2missing(df, title=None)[source]¶

Plot the expected-to-missing beats chart.

Parameters:

  • df (pandas.DataFrame) – The DataFrame containing SQA metrics per segment.

  • title (str) – The title of the chart; by default, None.

Returns:

fig – The resulting figure of expected-to-missing beats per segment.

Return type:

plotly.graph_objects.Figure

Other Useful Functions¶

heartview.heartview.plot_ibi_from_ecg(df, x, y, segment, n_segments)[source]¶

Visualize an IBI series generated from ECG data.

Parameters:

  • df (pd.DataFrame) – The data frame containing the signal data.

  • x (str) – The column containing the x-axis value (e.g., ‘Time’).

  • y (str) – The column containing the IBI series (e.g., ‘IBI’).

  • segment (int, float) – The segment number. For example, segment 1 denotes the first segment of the recording.

  • n_segments (int, float) – The number of segments to be visualized; by default, 1.

Returns:

fig – The IBI series plot.

Return type:

matplotlib.axes.AxesSubplot

heartview.heartview.plot_signal(df, x, y, fs, seg_size=60, segment=1, n_segments=1, signal_type=None, peaks=None)[source]¶

Visualize a signal.

Parameters:

  • df (pandas.DataFrame) – The data frame containing the signal data.

  • x (str) – The column containing the x-axis value (e.g., ‘Time’).

  • y (str, list) – The column(s) of the signal data (y-axis values).

  • fs (int, float) – The sampling rate.

  • seg_size (int) – The size of the segment, in seconds; by default, 60.

  • segment (int, float, None) – The segment number; by default, 1. For example, segment 1 denotes the first segment of the recording. This argument can also be set to None if df contains a ‘Segment’ column.

  • n_segments (int, float) – The number of segments to be visualized; by default, 1.

  • signal_type (str) – The type of signal being plotted (i.e., ‘ecg’, ‘bvp’, ‘acc’, ‘ibi’); by default, None.

  • peaks (str) – The column containing peak occurrences, i.e., a sequence of 0 and/or 1 denoting False or True occurrences of peaks. By default, peaks will be plotted on the first trace.

Returns:

fig – The signal visualization.

Return type:

matplotlib.axes.AxesSubplot

heartview.heartview.segment_data(data, fs, seg_size)[source]¶

Segment data into specific window sizes.

Parameters:

  • data (pd.DataFrame) – The data frame containing the data to be segmented.

  • fs (int) – The sampling rate.

  • seg_size (int) – The window size, in seconds, into which the data should be segmented.

Returns:

df – The original data frame with data segmented with labels in a ‘Segment’ column.

Return type:

pd.DataFrame
